Introduction

Lots of posts about numbers recently, eh? Well, here's another: in which, we solve a Rubik's Cube.

Two dueling, and even contentious properties of Rubik's Cubes are (1) the massive number of possible scrambles, and (2) that any of these scrambles is only 20 or so (contentious) moves away from being returned to the solved state. Due to the at-first unintuitive idea that, no matter how many twists we apply to a Rubik's cube to make it thoroughly jumbled, it can be solved in just twenty moves, that number has been dubbed God's Number.2 For the sake of motivating this post, I choose to anthropomorphize the search space of solutions to be the Demon Number.

The goal of this post is then to mathematically describe the process of moving the pieces of a valid configuration of a standard 3x3x3 Rubik's cube, and –in doing so– smite the Demon Number.

Group Theory

I have a couple other poasts that provide brief summaries of basic group theory.3 If you're starting from zero, those might be worth checking out, but this post should also be comprehensive enough (in terms of definitions, perhaps not proofs) to fill in the gaps to get the average reader up to speed. If you feel out of your depth, that's the fault of my shite writing, and not at all an indication of the readers' competency. Also worth noting that this post largely stands on the shoulders of the research and lectures of Janet Chen,4 once again I offer my meager commentary and observations about the mathematics in terms of cubing.

A Group ⟨G,∗⟩\langle G, * \rangle⟨G,∗⟩ consists of a set GGG, and a binary operator ∗*∗ such that:

  1. GGG is closed under ∗*∗, that is if a,b∈Ga, b \in Ga,b∈G, then a∗b∈Ga * b \in Ga∗b∈G
  2. The operator ∗*∗ is associate: ∀a,b,c∈G\forall a, b, c \in G∀a,b,c∈G, a∗(b∗c)=(a∗b)∗ca * (b *c) = (a *b) * ca∗(b∗c)=(a∗b)∗c
  3. There exists exactly one identity element e∈Ge \in Ge∈G satisfying g=e∗g=g∗e,∀g∈Gg = e * g = g * e, \forall g \in Gg=e∗g=g∗e,∀g∈G
  4. Every element in GGG has exactly one inverse: ∀g∈G,∃h∈G\forall g \in G, \exists h \in G∀g∈G,∃h∈G such that g∗h=h∗g=eg * h = h * g = eg∗h=h∗g=e. We might also refer to the inverse hhh as g−1g^{-1}g−1.

The order of an element of a group g∈Gg \in Gg∈G is the smallest nnn such that gng^ngn is the identity. For example, the order of the sexy move M=RUR′U′M = RUR'U'M=RUR′U′ is six, since the move is a 6-cycle, meaning that 6 repetitions of that sequence of twists returns the cube to whatever state it started in, which is equivalent to the identity: doing nothing. The largest order of a move M∈GM \in GM∈G is 1260 – one such move is M=RU2D′BD′M = RU^2D'BD'M=RU2D′BD′ which is like the least sexy move.

Taxonomy of The Cube

For this post, I focus on only the original 3x3x3 cube ("The Cube"), but the techniques described later on can be (in some cases, non-trivially) generalized to other l×m×nl \times m \times nl×m×n cubes.

The standard cube is composed of 26 pieces (333^333 external faces −1- 1−1 center core piece which we can't see or meaningfully manipulate, so we don't have to worry about solving). There are 8 corners, 12 edges, and 6 center pieces; the center pieces we can also largely ignore since they are fixed in place relative to one another.5 One of the first intuitions that novice cubers acquire is that, for standard color schemes, white is opposite yellow, green opposite blue, and red opposite orange; with the additional piece of relative positioning information that yellow is left of orange and also adjacent to blue, we can form the complete standard color scheme.

The cube obviously has 6 faces, which we've established have positions derived from their fixed centers, allowing us to completely describe the "correct" solved position of any piece in terms of the face it belongs to. For example, listing a corner's faces in clockwise order unambiguously refers to precisely one piece.6

For example, urf\sf urfurf refers to the yellow, red, blue piece:

It is also conventional to refer to corner pieces by their face labels listed in clockwise order when the orientation matters. Edges only have two possible orientations, so there is less ambiguity.

Along with the pieces themselves, it's useful to uniquely denote the position they belong in: their cubicles. Cubicles form the skeleton of the cube; they do not move, but pieces move in and out of them.

A move is any 90º turn of a face.7 Thus, we have six primitive moves and their inverses (denoted with an apostrophe, or sometimes a negative superscript), from which we can completely manipulate the cube, for a total of 12 primitives:

{U,D,L,R,F,B,U′,D′,L′,R′,F′,B′}\{ U, D, L, R, F, B, U', D', L', R', F', B' \}{U,D,L,R,F,B,U′,D′,L′,R′,F′,B′}

I'll refer to this set of primitives as P\mathbb{P}P. Typically, (as in, in my head, I read the inverse moves as MMM "prime").8

As mentioned above, we have four distinct categories for pieces: corners, edges, centers, and core(s) – only two of which we care about (corners and edges) since the rest cannot be meaningfully manipulated. These categories are distinct since edges can never inhabit corner cubicles and vice versa.

The Demon Number

The complexity of the cube is given by the number of permutations of each piece in each possible cubicle, confounded with the number of possible orientations each piece can have in each cubicle. Straightforwardly, we arrive at:

8!⏟corner perms⋅12!⏟edge perms⋅38⏟corner orientation⋅212⏟edge orientation=519 quintillion\underbrace{8!}_{\text{corner perms} } \cdot \underbrace{12!}_{\text{edge perms}} \cdot \underbrace{3^8}_{\text{corner orientation}} \cdot \underbrace{2^{12}}_{\text{edge orientation}} = 519 \text{ quintillion}corner perms8!​​⋅edge perms12!​​⋅corner orientation38​​⋅edge orientation212​​=519 quintillion

The Demon Number.

Here, we delineate between permutation and orientation, which are likely familiar notions to any students of intermediate speed cubing techniques such as CFOP: a method where the executor first solves the (C)ross, then completes the (F)irst two layers, then (O)rients the pieces on the last later (OLL), and finally (P)ermutes the pieces of the last layer to their final positions (PLL).9

We'll shortly convince ourselves that –though daunting– this number/search space can be drastically thinned by discounting invalid configurations. For example, one single corner twist is considered an invalid configuration due to the concept of parity. Formal definitions of what a configuration is, what makes one valid are forthcoming, and what the hell parity means in the context of a puzzle-toy. Thus, our immediate goal is to widdle away at the Demon Number.

We say that a configuration or cube-state is valid if it can be reached from the initial, pristine and solved cube-state using only the legal moves described above. We call this solved configuration C0\mathcal C_0C0​. Notably absent from the list of legal moves is anything resembling "pealing the stickers off" or "just taking the pieces out." These are trash.

Though we have yet to show that the standard cube is in fact group, the general goal of "solving" is to produce a sequence of moves that can take us from any valid state to the solved state C0\mathcal C_0C0​.

The Cube is a Group, Dammit!

We can construct our cube group with the set of all possible moves GGG, which includes sequences of the primitive moves described above. Two moves are identicial if they result in the same configuration when applied to the cube. E.g.

U2≡U′U′≡UUU^2 \equiv U'U' \equiv UUU2≡U′U′≡UU

The group operation is composition, denoted ∘\circ∘, such that for M1,M2∈GM_1, M_2 \in GM1​,M2​∈G, M1∘M2M_1 \circ M_2M1​∘M2​ is the move consisting of M1M_1M1​ followed by M2M_2M2​. Note that, though M1∘M2M_1 \circ M_2M1​∘M2​ is clearly more than just one twist, we can refer to the composition as still just a single move. So, moves can be sequences of twists.

Thus, ⟨G,∘⟩\langle G, \circ \rangle⟨G,∘⟩ is a group since the behavior we've described adheres to the four fundamental properties of groups defined earlier:

  1. GGG is closed under ∘\circ∘ since, if M1,M2M_1, M_2M1​,M2​ are moves, M1∘M2M_1 \circ M_2M1​∘M2​ must also be a move.
  2. The identity on GGG is the no-op M∘e≡M,∀M∈GM \circ e \equiv M, \forall M \in GM∘e≡M,∀M∈G, so GGG has a right identity.
  3. If MMM is a move, we can reverse all the steps of MMM to get an inverse M′M'M′ which is also equivalent to the no-op eee, therefore every move in GGG also has a right inverse.
  4. Lastly, ∘\circ∘ is associative. Recal that a move is also described by the spacial permutation and orientation it leaves each piece in. If we care about the orientation of a piece, we write M(c)M(c)M(c) for the oriented cubicle that the piece ccc ends up in after application of move MMM, with the faces of M(c)M(c)M(c) written in the same order as the faces of ccc. That is, the first face of M(c)M(c)M(c) should end up in the first face of ccc, and so on.

For example, the move RRR puts the piece ur\sf urur in the br\sf brbr cubicle, with the u\sf uu face of the piece lying on the b\sf bb face of the cubicle and the r\sf rr face of the piece lying in the r\sf rr face of the cubicle. Thus, we would write R(ur)=brR(\sf{ur}) = \sf brR(ur)=br.

For the move M1∘M2M_1 \circ M_2M1​∘M2​ , M1M_1M1​ moves ccc to M1(c)M_1(c)M1​(c), and M2M_2M2​ moves it to M2(M1(c))M_2(M_1(c))M2​(M1​(c)), so

(M1∘M2)(c)≡M2(M1(c))(M_1 \circ M_2)(c) \equiv M_2(M_1(c))(M1​∘M2​)(c)≡M2​(M1​(c))

To show that ∘\circ∘ is associative, we need to show that

(M1∘M2)∘M3≡M1∘(M2∘M3)(M_1 \circ M_2) \circ M_3 \equiv M_1 \circ (M_2 \circ M_3)(M1​∘M2​)∘M3​≡M1​∘(M2​∘M3​)

for all M1,M2,M3∈GM_1, M_2, M_3 \in GM1​,M2​,M3​∈G. That is, both the sinistral side and dextral sides of this equivalence relation must do the same thing to every piece ccc, leaving the cube in identical configurations.

  [(M1∘M2)∘M3](c)≡[M1∘(M2∘M3)](c)M3([M1∘M2])(c)≡(M2∘M3)(M1(c))M3(M2(M1(c)))≡M3(M2(M1(c)))\begin{aligned} \; [(M_1 \circ M_2) \circ M_3] (c) &\equiv [M_1 \circ (M_2 \circ M_3)](c) \\ M_3([M_1 \circ M_2])(c) &\equiv (M_2 \circ M_3)(M_1(c)) \\ M_3(M_2(M_1(c))) &\equiv M_3(M_2(M_1(c))) \end{aligned}[(M1​∘M2​)∘M3​](c)M3​([M1​∘M2​])(c)M3​(M2​(M1​(c)))​≡[M1​∘(M2​∘M3​)](c)≡(M2​∘M3​)(M1​(c))≡M3​(M2​(M1​(c)))​

So, composition is associative, and therefore ⟨G,∘⟩\langle G, \circ \rangle⟨G,∘⟩ is a group!

Subgroups and Generators

The Demon Number is frightening because, in order to find our solution, we have sparse moves in an infinite10 search space. To hack away at the :ghost: spooky number, we first want to examine the subgroups of GGG to extract any patterns or properties that might be helpful in our quest.

Any nonempty subset HHH of GGG (H⊆G,H≠∅)(H \subseteq G, H \neq \varnothing)(H⊆G,H​=∅) is called a subgroup of GGG.11 A group is always a subset of itself.

Let ⟨G,∘⟩\langle G, \circ \rangle⟨G,∘⟩ be a group. A nonempty subset HHH of GGG is a subgroup of GGG iff ∀a,b∈H,ab−1∈H\forall a,b \in H, ab^{-1} \in H∀a,b∈H,ab−1∈H.12

If HHH is a subgroup of some group GGG, we say that HHH generates GGG if G=⟨S⟩G = \langle S\rangleG=⟨S⟩; that is, every element of GGG can be written as a finite product (under group operation, whatever it is) of elements of SSS and its inverses.

This is useful in reducing The Demon Number since we can more thoroughly state that center positions need not be considered.13

Peter uses subgroups, it's super effective.

The Symmetric Group and Cycles

Recall that there are 8!8!8! possible positions of the set of corners in the cubicles. To better understand how these possibilities impact our solution attempts, consider the general case of configuring nnn objects labeled 1,2,...,n1, 2, ..., n1,2,...,n into nnn buckets, similarly labeled.

We define a bijection between pieces and labeled cubicles:

σ:{1,2,...,n}→{1,2,...,n}\sigma: \{ 1, 2, ..., n\} \rightarrow \{ 1, 2, ..., n\}σ:{1,2,...,n}→{1,2,...,n}

by σ(i)\sigma(i)σ(i) being assigned to the object put into slot iii, where 1≤i≤n1 \leq i \leq n1≤i≤n.

The symmetric group on nnn letters is the set of bijections from {1,2,...,n}→{1,2,...,n}\{ 1, 2, ..., n\} \rightarrow \{ 1, 2, ..., n\}{1,2,...,n}→{1,2,...,n}, with the operation of composition; we write this group as SnS_nSn​.

For example, let σ,τ∈S3\sigma, \tau \in S_3σ,τ∈S3​ be defined by

σ(1)=3,  τ(1)=1σ(2)=1,  τ(2)=3σ(3)=2,  τ(3)=2\begin{aligned} \sigma(1) = 3, \; \tau(1) = 1 \\ \sigma(2) = 1, \; \tau(2) = 3 \\ \sigma(3) = 2, \; \tau(3) = 2 \\ \end{aligned}σ(1)=3,τ(1)=1σ(2)=1,τ(2)=3σ(3)=2,τ(3)=2​

which implies

(στ)(1)=τ(3)=2(στ)(2)=τ(1)=1(στ)(3)=τ(2)=3\begin{aligned} (\sigma\tau)(1) = \tau(3) = 2 \\ (\sigma\tau)(2) = \tau(1) = 1 \\ (\sigma\tau)(3) = \tau(2) = 3 \end{aligned}(στ)(1)=τ(3)=2(στ)(2)=τ(1)=1(στ)(3)=τ(2)=3​

Notice that these subsets of the symmetric group, as well as their composition, form cycles. We can express cycles in groups as

σ(i  j  k  l)(m  n)(o)\sigma(i \; j \;k \; l)(m \; n)(o)σ(ijkl)(mn)(o)

where σ(i)=j,σ(j)=k,...,σ(l)=i\sigma(i) = j, \sigma(j) = k, ..., \sigma(l) = iσ(i)=j,σ(j)=k,...,σ(l)=i and so on. So we have three cycles in this arbitrary mapping σ∈Swhatever\sigma \in S_\text{whatever}σ∈Swhatever​.

Formally, a cycle (i1  i2  ...  ik)(i_1 \; i_2 \; ... \; i_k)(i1​i2​...ik​) is the element τ∈Sn\tau \in S_nτ∈Sn​ defined by

τ(i1)=i2,τ(i2)=i3,...,τ(ik−1)=ik,τ(ik)=i1\tau(i_1) = i_2, \tau(i_2) = i_3, ..., \tau(i_{k-1}) = i_k, \tau(i_k) = i_1τ(i1​)=i2​,τ(i2​)=i3​,...,τ(ik−1​)=ik​,τ(ik​)=i1​

where τ(j)=j\tau(j) = jτ(j)=j if j≠ir,∀rj \neq i_r, \forall rj​=ir​,∀r. The length of a cycle is kkk and the support of the cycle is the set {i1,...,ik}\{ i_1, ..., i_k\}{i1​,...,ik​} of elements which appear in the cycle, denoted supp τ\text{supp } \tausupp τ.

Two cycles σ,τ\sigma, \tauσ,τ are disjoint if they have no supporting elements in common: supp σ  ∩  supp τ=∅\text{supp } \sigma \; \cap \; \text{supp } \tau = \varnothingsupp σ∩supp τ=∅.

If σ∈Sn\sigma \in S_nσ∈Sn​ is the product of disjoint cycles of lengths k1,k2,...,krk_1, k_2, ..., k_rk1​,k2​,...,kr​ (including its 1-cycles), then the integers k1,k2,...,krk_1, k_2, ..., k_rk1​,k2​,...,kr​ are the cycle-type of σ\sigmaσ.

Applying this ish to The Cube

We can use a modified cycle notation to describe what happens to each corner piece after applying a move to a configuration with respect to both its permutation and its face's orientations.

To illustrate this, we "unfold" part of the cube and examine the partial diagram of its faces after a DDD move, we can see the effect the move has on all the pieces in that slice.

We can describe this effect on a single piece, e.g. D(dlf)=dfrD(\sf {dlf}) = \sf{dfr}D(dlf)=dfr since the piece dlf\sf {dlf}dlf goes to the dfr\sf {dfr}dfr cubicle. Using the above cycle notation, we can describe the effect for all the impacted pieces as:

D=(dlf  dfr  drb  dbl)(df  dr  db  dl)D = (\sf{dlf} \; \sf{dfr} \; \sf{drb} \; \sf{dbl})(\sf{df} \; \sf{dr} \; \sf{db} \; \sf{dl})D=(dlfdfrdrbdbl)(dfdrdbdl)

where each piece just traverses the clockwise orbit around the d\sf dd centerpiece.

Configurations

Recall that a configuration is completely described by:

  1. The positions of the corners
  2. The positions of the edges
  3. The orientations of the corners
  4. The orientations of the edges

1 and 2 can be described by σ∈S8,τ∈S12\sigma \in S_8, \tau \in S_{12}σ∈S8​,τ∈S12​ respectively, where S8,S12S_8, S_{12}S8​,S12​ are the symmetric sets of moves that take the corners or edges from their starting positions to new positions.

To tackle 3 and 4, we need some more notation to describe the orientation of a piece relative to its starting state.

Corner Configuration

Each corner has three possible orientations which we number 0,1,20, 1, 20,1,2. We then systematically label each face of every corner cubicle:

1→u∈ufl5→d∈dbl2→u∈urf6→d∈dlf3→u∈ubr7→d∈dfr4→u∈ulb8→d∈drb\begin{aligned} 1 &\rightarrow \sf{u} \in \sf{ufl} \quad &5 &\rightarrow \sf{d} \in \sf{dbl} \\ 2 &\rightarrow \sf{u} \in \sf{urf} \quad &6 &\rightarrow \sf{d} \in \sf{dlf} \\ 3 &\rightarrow \sf{u} \in \sf{ubr} &7 &\rightarrow \sf{d} \in \sf{dfr} \\ 4 &\rightarrow \sf{u} \in \sf{ulb} &8 &\rightarrow \sf{d} \in \sf{drb} \end{aligned}1234​→u∈ufl→u∈urf→u∈ubr→u∈ulb​5678​→d∈dbl→d∈dlf→d∈dfr→d∈drb​

So each corner piece has 1 face lying in a labeled cubicle. We label this corner face 000, then continue around the cube clockwise, labeling the other corner faces 111 and 222.

Now, each corner piece has each face labeled. For any integer i∈[1,8]i \in [1, 8]i∈[1,8], we can find the cubicle face with that label, and let xix_ixi​ be the number of the corner piece face which indicates its orientation on this face. This gives us an ordered 8-tuple

x=(x1,x2,...,x8)\mathbf {x} = (x_1, x_2, ..., x_8)x=(x1​,x2​,...,x8​)

which contains all the corner orientation information for a configuration. We can think of each xi∈xx_i \in \mathbf {x}xi​∈x as the number of clockwise twists that that corner iii is away from having it's 000-face in the numbered face of the cubicle (the solved orientation). Observe that a corner piece that is 3 twists away from being solved is identically oriented to that of a piece which is already solved (0 twists away), so we can think of elements of each xix_ixi​ as being elements of the Z/3Z\mathbb Z / 3\mathbb ZZ/3Z. Thus, x\mathbf xx is an 8-tuple of elements of Z/3Z\mathbb Z / 3\mathbb ZZ/3Z, where each element xi∈(Z/3Z)8x_i \in (\mathbb Z / 3\mathbb Z)^8xi​∈(Z/3Z)8.

x=(x1=0x2=1x4=0x3=2x5=0x7=2x6=0x8=1)=(0,1,2,2,0,0,2,1)\mathbf x = \Bigg ( \begin{aligned} x_1 = 0 \quad &x_2 = 1 \\ x_4 = 0 \quad &x_3 = 2 \\ x_5 = 0 \quad &x_7 = 2 \\ x_6 = 0 \quad &x_8 = 1 \\ \end{aligned} \Bigg )= (0,1,2,2,0,0,2,1) x=(x1​=0x4​=0x5​=0x6​=0​x2​=1x3​=2x7​=2x8​=1​)=(0,1,2,2,0,0,2,1)

Edge Configuration

We can repeat this same labeling process for edges. First, we assign cubicle labels (somewhat arbitrarily, as long as the system is internally consistent):

1→u∈ub5→b∈lb9→d∈db2→u∈ur6→b∈rb10→d∈dr3→u∈uf7→f∈rf11→d∈df4→u∈ul8→f∈lf12→d∈dl\begin{aligned} 1 &\rightarrow \sf{u} \in \sf{ub} \quad &5 &\rightarrow \sf{b} \in \sf{lb} &9 &\rightarrow \sf{d} \in \sf{db} \\ 2 &\rightarrow \sf{u} \in \sf{ur} \quad &6 &\rightarrow \sf{b} \in \sf{rb} &10 &\rightarrow \sf{d} \in \sf{dr} \\ 3 &\rightarrow \sf{u} \in \sf{uf} \quad &7 &\rightarrow \sf{f} \in \sf{rf} &11 &\rightarrow \sf{d} \in \sf{df} \\ 4 &\rightarrow \sf{u} \in \sf{ul} \quad &8 &\rightarrow \sf{f} \in \sf{lf} &12 &\rightarrow \sf{d} \in \sf{dl} \\ \end{aligned}1234​→u∈ub→u∈ur→u∈uf→u∈ul​5678​→b∈lb→b∈rb→f∈rf→f∈lf​9101112​→d∈db→d∈dr→d∈df→d∈dl​

Each piece now has a face lying on a numbered edge cubicle. We label this edge face 000 and the other one 111. We let yiy_iyi​ be the number of the edge piece face in the cubicle face labeled iii yielding

y∈(Z/2Z)12\mathbf y \in (\mathbb Z / 2 \mathbb Z)^{12}y∈(Z/2Z)12

With this orientation notation, we can completely describe any configuration of

σ∈S8,τ∈S12x∈(Z/3Z)8,y∈(Z/2Z)12\begin{aligned} \sigma &\in S_8, &\tau &\in S_{12} \\ \mathbf x &\in (\mathbb Z / 3 \mathbb Z)^{8}, &\mathbf y &\in (\mathbb Z / 2 \mathbb Z)^{12} \end{aligned}σx​∈S8​,∈(Z/3Z)8,​τy​∈S12​∈(Z/2Z)12​

as a 4-tuple C=(σ,τ,x,y)\mathcal C = (\sigma, \tau, \mathbf x, \mathbf y)C=(σ,τ,x,y).

Example

A common algorithm used in the beginner's method during the last step –orienting the corners of the last face– is a six-cycle DRD′R′DRD'R'DRD′R′.14 If we jot down the 4-tuple for this algorithm, we get:

D=(dlf  dfr  drb  dbl)(df  dr  db  dl)R=(rfu  rub  rbd  rdf)(ru  rb  rd  rf)\begin{aligned} D = (\sf{dlf} \; \sf{dfr} \; \sf{drb} \; \sf{dbl})(\sf{df} \; \sf{dr} \; \sf{db} \; \sf{dl}) \\ R = (\sf{rfu} \; \sf{rub} \; \sf{rbd} \; \sf{rdf})(\sf{ru} \; \sf{rb} \; \sf{rd} \; \sf{rf}) \\ \end{aligned}D=(dlfdfrdrbdbl)(dfdrdbdl)R=(rfurubrbdrdf)(rurbrdrf)​

from which, we also get their inverses:

D′=(dbl  drb  dfr  dlf)(dl  db  dr  df)R′=(rdf  rbd  rub  rfu)(rf  rd  rb  ru)\begin{aligned} D' = (\sf{dbl} \; \sf{drb} \; \sf{dfr} \; \sf{dlf})(\sf{dl} \; \sf{db} \; \sf{dr} \; \sf{df}) \\ R' = (\sf{rdf} \; \sf{rbd} \; \sf{rub} \; \sf{rfu})(\sf{rf} \; \sf{rd} \; \sf{rb} \; \sf{ru}) \\ \end{aligned}D′=(dbldrbdfrdlf)(dldbdrdf)R′=(rdfrbdrubrfu)(rfrdrbru)​

So, the composition of the crycles listed in the complete algorithm DRD′R′DRD'R'DRD′R′ is:

DRD′R′=(dlf  dfr  lfd  frd  fdl  rdf)(drb  bru  bdr  ubr  rbd  rub)(df  dr  br)\begin{aligned} DRD'R' = (\sf{dlf} \; \sf{dfr} \; \sf{lfd} \; \sf{frd} \; \sf{fdl} \; \sf{rdf}) (\sf{drb} \; \sf{bru} \; \sf{bdr} \; \sf{ubr} \; \sf{rbd}\; \sf{rub})(\sf{df} \; \sf{dr} \; \sf{br}) \\ \end{aligned}DRD′R′=(dlfdfrlfdfrdfdlrdf)(drbbrubdrubrrbdrub)(dfdrbr)​

which has two 6-cycles in terms of corner orientation, and a single 3-cycle in terms of edges.15

Recall that τ\tauτ, an element of S12S_{12}S12​, is a bijection from the set of 12 un-oriented edges to the 12 edge cubicles, and can be expressed in disjoint cycle notation. A homomorphism is a weaker condition than the structural and relational equivalence defined by an isomorphism. A homorphism exists when sets have the same algebraic structure, but they might have a different number of elements.

Formally, if we let ⟨G,⋄⟩\langle G, \diamond \rangle⟨G,⋄⟩ and ⟨H,⋆⟩\langle H, \star \rangle⟨H,⋆⟩ be two groups. A homomorphism from GGG to HHH is a map ϕ:G→H\phi: G \rightarrow Hϕ:G→H such that

The Sign Homomorphism

We know from properties of generators that SnS_nSn​ is generated by the 2-cycles in SnS_nSn​. That is, any permutation in SnS_nSn​ can be written as a finite product of 2-cycles. However, any given permutation of SnS_nSn​ can be written as a finite product of 2-cycles in infinitely many ways (actually infinite, not just like "big numbie" infinity). So this isn't super useful.

Some permutations in SnS_nSn​ can be expressed as a product of even number 2-cycles; aptly referred to as even permutations. Conversely, all the other permutations of SnS_nSn​, written as a product of an odd number of 2-cycles are called odd permutations. At the moment, it might seem like there's no reason why a permutation couldn't be both odd and even, but as the name suggests: that is –in fact– impossible.

The direct proof is gross, so we'll indirectly approach this statement.

The Alternating Group and Parity

Like the set of real numbers, the parity of a group is multiplicative. That is, the product of an even permutation and an odd permutation is odd, the product of two even permutations or two odd permutations as even. The inverse of an even permutation is even, the inverse of an odd is odd, so we can define a subgroup of of the symmetric group consisting of all even permutations called the Alternating Group: An⊂SnA_n \subset S_nAn​⊂Sn​:

An={σ  ∣  ϵ(σ)=1,σ∈Sn}A_n = \{\sigma \; \vert \; \epsilon(\sigma) = 1, \sigma \in S_n \}An​={σ∣ϵ(σ)=1,σ∈Sn​}

If M∈GM \in GM∈G is a face twist, then ϕcube(M)\phi_{cube}(M)ϕcube​(M) is a product of two 4-cycles. A 4-cycle:

(m1  m2  m3  m4)=(m1  m2)(m1  m3)(m1  m4)(m_1 \; m_2 \; m_3 \; m_4) = (m_1 \; m_2)(m_1 \; m_3)(m_1 \; m_4)(m1​m2​m3​m4​)=(m1​m2​)(m1​m3​)(m1​m4​)

is a product of an odd number of 2-cycles, is also odd, so two 4-cycles is even. Therefore ϕcube(M)\phi_{cube}(M)ϕcube​(M) is even. And since the face twists generate all of GGG, ϕcube\phi_{cube}ϕcube​ is even for all M∈GM \in GM∈G. So ϕcube(M)∈A20∀M∈G\phi_{cube}(M) \in A_{20} \forall M \in Gϕcube​(M)∈A20​∀M∈G.

Recall that ϕcube(M)=ϕcorner(M)ϕedge(M)\phi_{cube}(M) = \phi_{corner}(M)\phi_{edge}(M)ϕcube​(M)=ϕcorner​(M)ϕedge​(M), so either the edge homomorphism or corner homomorphism are both even, or both odd– but they must have the same sign. So, for any valid configuration C\mathcal CC, the sign of σ,τ\sigma, \tauσ,τ must be the same.

Kernels

The kernel of a homomorphism ϕ:G→H\phi: G \rightarrow Hϕ:G→H is defined to be the pre-image of the identity of ggg in GGG

ker(ϕ)={g  ∣  ϕ(g)=1H,g∈G}\text{ker}(\phi) = \{ g \; \vert \; \phi(g) =1_H, g \in G\}ker(ϕ)={g∣ϕ(g)=1H​,g∈G}

The kernel consists of all moves of the cube which do not change the permutations of any pieces. That is, only the moves that change the orientations, which is straightforwardly useful. In particular, AnA_nAn​ is the kernel of ϵ:Sn→{−1,1}\epsilon: S_n \rightarrow \{-1, 1\}ϵ:Sn​→{−1,1}.

Group Actions

If the cube is in some configuration C\mathcal CC, the applying some move M1∈GM_1 \in GM1​∈G takes the cube state to a new configuration we call C∘M1\mathcal C \circ M_1C∘M1​. If we take another move M2∈GM_2 \in GM2​∈G, we can compose or chain the resulting states together:

(C∘M1)∘M2(\mathcal C \circ M_1) \circ M_2(C∘M1​)∘M2​

which is the same as executing (M1∘M2)(M_1 \circ M_2)(M1​∘M2​) on C\mathcal CC directly. This is the essence of group actions.

Formally, a right Group Action of ⟨G,∘⟩\langle G, \circ \rangle⟨G,∘⟩ on a non-empty set AAA is a map A×G→AA \times G \rightarrow AA×G→A. That is, given a∈A,g∈Ga \in A, g\in Ga∈A,g∈G we can produce another element of AAA, for which we write a⋅ga \cdot ga⋅g satisfying the following properties:

  1. (a⋅g1)⋅g2=a⋅(g1∘g2);∀g1,g2∈G,a∈A(a \cdot g_1) \cdot g_2 = a \cdot (g_1 \circ g_2); \quad \forall g_1, g_2 \in G, a \in A(a⋅g1​)⋅g2​=a⋅(g1​∘g2​);∀g1​,g2​∈G,a∈A
  2. a⋅e=a;∀a∈Aa \cdot e = a; \quad \forall a\in Aa⋅e=a;∀a∈A

These are called right group actions since we associate group elements on the right. When we have a group action of GGG on AAA, we say that "GGG acts on AAA." GGG acts on the set of configurations of the cube (both valid and invalid).

Oftentimes, we are interested in the case where the set AAA is the group itself. For a,g∈Ga, g \in Ga,g∈G we def a⋅g=aga \cdot g = aga⋅g=ag to just be group multiplication. If GGG acts on a set AAA, the orbit of a∈Aa \in Aa∈A under this action is the set {ag  ∣  g∈G}\{ ag \; \vert \; g \in G \}{ag∣g∈G}. We can think of orbits as the configurations that are reachable by repeating some (sequence of) move(s).

If GGG acts on the set of configurations of the cube, the orbit of the starting configuration under this action is exactly the set of valid configurations of the cube. This is a super nifty tid bit which further eradicates the spookiness of the Demon Number.

If a group action only has one orbit, we say that the action is transitive, or that the group acts transitively. We often want to prove something about all the elements of an orbit, like oh I don't know, all valid configurations of a cube.

Suppose a finite group GGG acts on a set AAA, and let SSS be a set of generators of GGG, and PPP be some set of conditions such that the following is true: whenever a∈Aa \in Aa∈A satisfies PPP and s∈Ss \in Ss∈S, a⋅sa \cdot sa⋅s also satisfies PPP. Then, if a0∈Aa_0 \in Aa0​∈A satisfies PPP, then every element in the orbit of a0a_0a0​ also satisfies PPP! In the case of the cube, we will apply this theorem to the action of GGG on the set AAA of configurations, where S=P,a0=C0S = \mathbb P, a_0 = \mathcal C_0S=P,a0​=C0​ in order to prove other statements about the set of valid configurations.

Pragmatically speaking, GGG acts on the set of configurations of the cube. The valid configurations, then, form a single orbit of this action, so it makes sense that the statements we make about valid configations can be generalized to other orbits.

This proof also tells us that the demon number can be dodecimated from 212388!12!2^{12}3^88!12!212388!12! to 112\frac{1}{12}121​ of this number due to the elimination of invalid conigurations. For these cubes, we do need to consider the orientation of the center pieces relative to their surrounding edges, but their positions are still fixed. For even-dimensional cubes, those that do not have single, fixed-position center pieces some of the theorems relating to parity do not hold (as they're specified for the odd-dimensional cubes). Nonetheless, commutators discussed later can still be applied to form the centers and solve resulting parity issues introduced by the absence of fixed centers.
